title-group.article-title: The last word on the so-called ‘Rowell’s syndrome’?

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Medical and Surgical Critical Care, Section of Clinical, Allergo-immunological and Infettivological Dermatology, University of Florence, Florence, Italy; and 2Department of Clinical Physiopathology, University of Florence, Florence, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Emiliano Antiga, MD, Department of Medical and Surgical Critical Care, Section of Clinical, Allergo-immunological and Infettivological Dermatology, University of Florence, Piazza Indipendenza, 11, 50129 Florence, Italy Email: emiliano.antiga@unifi.it

abstract.p: To date, 71 patients having the so-called ‘Rowell’s syndrome’ (RS) have been reported in the literature. However, most of them did not show all the clinical and serological features first described by Rowell and co-workers in 1963. Moreover, since then, subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE) has been identified and the diagnostic criteria as well as the clinical features of erythema multiforme (EM) defined. Accordingly several authors have questioned the existence of RS over the past years. In the present paper, the main clinical, histopathological and immunopathological features of both SCLE and EM are described and all of the cases of RS reported in the literature are also reviewed in depth. A real association between discoid LE and EM was present only in a minority of cases and could be considered a mere coincidence. As for other associations, e.g. those between CLE and lichen planus or psoriasis, the coexistence of CLE and EM does not justify the framing of a separate syndrome as suggested by Rowell et al.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In 1963, Rowell, Beck and Anderson1 described four female patients presenting with the clinical picture of chronic discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) associated with annular lesions, clinically and histologically resembling erythema multiforme (EM). All patients also showed erythrocyanosis of the legs and chilblains.

These patients had typical immunological findings, consisting of the speckled type of antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), the anti-SjT type of precipitating antibodies to saline extract of human tissue and positive rheumatoid factor (RF). Later, it turned out that anti-SjT antibodies are identical to those of anti-La/SSB and anti-Ro/SSA.2 Rowell et al. stated that this association of a distinctive clinical picture with specific immunological alterations was sufficiently characteristic to justify regarding it as a new syndrome.

Since 1963, 71 patients having the so-called Rowell’s syndrome (RS) have been reported in the literature. However, most of them did not show all the clinical and serological features firstly described by Rowell and co-workers. Since then, a new specific type of cutaneous LE (CLE), namely subacute CLE (SCLE), was identified,3,4 and the diagnostic criteria as well as the clinical features of EM defined.5 Accordingly, several authors have questioned the existence of RS over the past years.6–8

In the present paper, the main clinical, histopathological and immunopathological features of both SCLE and EM are described. We also review in depth all the cases of RS reported in the literature, in order to answer the question of whether RS should be regarded as a distinct clinical entity or simply as an incidental association between LE and EM.

sec.title: Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus: clinical and immunopathological findings
sec.p: In 1977, Gilliam reported a particular subset of CLE, with specific clinical and serological features, occurring preferentially in white females, and called it SCLE.3 SCLE was then better defined by Sontheimer et al. in 1979;9 it shows a significant coincidence with HLA-DR2, -DR3, -DQ2 and DRw52,10 and occurs in 7–27% of patients with LE, mostly Caucasian females of all ages.4,9

Certain drugs, especially hydrochlorothiazide, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and calcium channel blockers, have been associated with the onset and/or exacerbation of this disease.11,12 In recent years, terbinafine has also been reported to induce SCLE.13 Patients with SCLE typically have prominent cutaneous and musculoskeletal complaints, do not generally develop a severe systemic disease, and only half of them have four or more American College of Rheumatology (ACR) criteria for the diagnosis of systemic LE (SLE).14,15

Initially, SCLE lesions present with erythematous papules that evolve into scaly papulosquamous or annular/polycyclic plaques.9 A recent study of our group found that 42% of the patients with SCLE studied show the annular/polycyclic form, 39% papulosquamous form, and 16% both manifestations.16 Generally, lesions of this subtype heal without scarring but can leave long-lasting and permanent hypochromic changes, both representing a ‘clue’ for the clinical diagnosis.17

SCLE shows a characteristic distribution of lesions on sun-exposed areas, in particular the upper chest and back, deltoids, extensor surface of the arms, and less often face and scalp.16,17 Interestingly, 27–100% of patients with SCLE have been reported to be abnormally photosensitive. Phototest results were shown to be positive in 63% of instances after UVA or UVB irradiation. Exposure to UV can precipitate or worsen SCLE lesions.18 Photosensitizing medications were demonstrated to trigger photo-induced reactions in SCLE patients.19
Several other skin lesions that are not specific for LE have been described in patients with SCLE, including painless mucous membrane erosions.20

Patients with SCLE may develop localized facial acute CLE, which has been seen in 7–100% of patients.21,22 Several reports have also highlighted that up to 29% of patients with SCLE develop DLE lesions during their clinical course20,21,23 and, interestingly, 19% of the original cohort of patients with SCLE had classical DLE.9

In 60–80% of SCLE patients, ANAs are detected when human tissue is used as a substrate.23,24 With immunodiffusion techniques, anti-Ro/SSA antibodies have been detected in 40–100% of patients with SCLE,25 while anti-La/SSBs have been observed in 12–42%.26 The Ro/SSA antibodies are directed against ribonucleoproteins consisting of a 60 kD peptide and an antigenically distinct 52 kD polypeptide.27,28 Anti-dsDNA antibodies have been reported in 1.2–10% of SCLE patients.20,29 RF is present in approximately one-third of the patients.20,24

Several unusual clinical subtypes of SCLE have been reported. Massone et al. reported a case of SCLE with EM-like cutaneous lesions.30 Lyon et al. reported two cases of delayed diagnosis of SCLE because of the clinical and histopathological similarities between SCLE and EM.31 Grant,32 and Wechsler and Stourides33 reported some SCLE patients with lesions resembling erythema annulare centrifugum. In these patients, the active edge of the annular SCLE lesions undergoes vesicular changes followed by squamous-crusted lesions. Vesiculo-bullous changes, associated with focal areas of necrosis upon histology, were present in 38% of the cases reported by Herrero et al.34 In a case reported by Bielsa et al., the annular edges progressed to mimic toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).35 Other rare clinical variants include erythroderma,36 vitiligo-like,37 pytiriasis-like38 and generalized poichiloderma.39
Recently, in a series of patients with drug-induced SCLE, in five out of 11 patients annular-polycyclic and targetoid EM-like lesions occurred simultaneously.40

sec.title: Erythema multiforme
sec.p: According to the International Group on Severe Cutaneous Adverse Reactions, EM (including EM minus, EM maius, and mucosal EM) features typical clinical, histopathological and immunopathological findings.5,41,42 Most importantly, EM is to be differentiated from ‘acute disseminated epidermal necrolysis’, which includes Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS), TEN and the SJS/TEN overlap.42

Often preceded by prodromic symptoms, EM is characterized by the occurrence of several long-lasting, symmetric, typical or atypical raised target lesions on the hands, the feet and the extensor aspects of the limbs.43–45

Typical targets were defined as individual lesions measuring less than 3 cm in diameter with a regular round shape, a well-defined border and at least three different zones, that is, two concentric rings around a central disk. One ring consists of palpable oedema, paler than the central disk.40–45
Atypical raised targets were defined as round, oedematous palpable lesions, resembling typical targets but with only two zones and/or poorly-defined borders.40–42

By contrast, atypical flat targets (which are characteristic of SJS) were defined as round lesions resembling those of EM but with only two zones and/or a poorly-defined border, that are not palpable with the exception of a potentially present central blister.40–45

Mucosal lesions, which are absent in EM minus and always present in EM maius, are most often limited to the oral cavity (lips, non-attached gingivae and the ventral side of the tongue), and consist of erosions with fibrin deposits. Intact vesicles or blisters are rarely seen.46
Mucosal EM, also called ectodermosis pluriorificialis, is a rare condition characterized by severe involvement of two or three mucosal sites in the absence of skin lesions.42

EM is considered a relatively common disease, but its real incidence is not known. It occurs in patients of all ages, but mostly in adolescents and young adults, with a slight male predominance (male to female ratio = 3 : 2).5,43 Genetic predisposition has been reported, with 66% of EM patients featuring the HLA-DQB1*0301 allele (which is present in only 31% of healthy subjects).47

Most cases of EM are related to infections, herpes virus definitely being the most common cause.48–50 Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the second major cause of EM and may even be the most frequent aetiologic agent in paediatric cases.51,52 Many other infections (bacterial or viral: varicella-zoster virus, parvovirus B19, hepatitis B and C viruses, Epstein-Barr virus) have been reported in individual cases or small series, but the evidence for these agents is only circumstantial.53 Drugs are rare causes of EM, and are believed to induce only cases with mucous membrane lesions.44,53

sec.title: Rowell’s syndrome: review of the literature
sec.p:
To date, 71 patients with RS have been described.1,6–8,54–88 The most relevant features of such cases are reported in Table 1. Table 1

F: female, M: male, RF: rheumatoid factor, p.: patient, + : positive, –: negative,?: uncertain, NR: not reported, SLE: systemic lupus erythematosus, DLE: discoid LE, SCLE: subacute cutaneous LE, SS: Sjögren’s syndrome, TEN: toxic epidermal necrolysis, Sp: speckled, Hom: homogeneous, APS: antiphospholipid syndrome. a
Morphology not defined. b
Title not defined.

As shown in Table 2, the clinical and immunological features reported by Rowell et al. in their first description in 1963 (and then defined as major and minor diagnostic criteria of RS by Zeitouni et al. in 200070) are present only in a minority of the cases reported in the literature. Table 2
Frequency of the clinical and immunological criteria in the cases diagnosed as RS
Frequency in Rowell et al. (four patients)1 Frequency in all the remaining reported cases (67 patients)6–8,54–88
Clinical features
DLE lesions 100% 18/54 (33.3%)
EP-like lesions 100% 65/67 (97%)b
Perniosis (chilblain lupus) 100% 10/67 (14.9%)
Immunological features
ANA (speckled) 100% 29/48 (60.4%)
Ro/SSAa 100%a 23/39 (59%)
La/SSBa 100%a 14/39 (35.9%)
Rheumatoid factor 100% 18/42 (42.9%)
a
Anti-SjT precipitating antibodies to saline extract of human tissue are identical to Ro/SSA, La/SSB antibodies. b
Typical annular-polycyclic SCLE lesions were described in two cases20,36 and an overlap between EM and SJS in one case;35 in two cases, skin lesions clinically suggestive for EM showed histopathological features typical of LE.85

Instead, in the majority of cases present in the literature, both DLE lesions and perniosis (chilblain lupus), which were two of the main clinical features of the cases reported by Rowell et al.,1 are lacking. By contrast, several other types of CLE are reported, including 15 cases of malar rash (which was associated with chronic CLE in one case73), one case of diffuse maculo-papular rash,78 one case of bullous LE77 and one case of necrotic lesions associated with anti-phospholipid syndrome.67,73 In other cases, annular-polycyclic SCLE lesions have been described.65,66,70 In 13 patients with a diagnosis of SLE, specific CLE lesions were absent, while in 17 patients they were not described or not specific.

Systemic manifestations present in SLE patients included lupus nephritis, serositis (pericarditis) and systemic vasculitis. Furthermore, one case was associated with Sjögren's syndrome,74 one case with rheumatoid arthritis81 and one case with histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis.64

With regard to the skin lesions of EM, typical raised targets were reported very rarely, while in several cases the lesions were described as figurate, flat, annular lesions – probably more consistent with the annular-polycyclic variant of SCLE than with EM. Moreover, in the majority of cases an accurate morphological description of the cutaneous lesions was lacking and the clinical photographs, when present, were not of a good quality.

Interestingly, in two cases the lesions were clinically suggestive for SCLE, while the histopathological findings were consistent with EM.73,84 By contrast, two other cases presented with clinically typical EM lesions, while the histopathological examination revealed the presence of LE features.85 Finally, one of the cases reported was consistent with SJS/TEN overlap syndrome,83 whilst in two cases the initial clinical manifestations were suggestive for EM but, in the following relapses, clinical and histopathological features of TEN were observed.72

All these data suggest the difficulties of clinically distinguishing between the annular-polycyclic type of SCLE and EM, particularly if the EM diagnostic criteria suggested by Assier et al. are not used.5 Furthermore, it is also challenging to differentiate between these two entities on the basis of the histopathological findings. As an example, necrotic keratinocytes can be found not only in EM,74 but also in SCLE skin lesions, as suggested by Herrero et al., who recently reported the presence of this histopathological finding in six out of 13 (54%) SCLE patients.89

Three out of four patients of the original case series by Rowell1 lack the histopathological description of EM-like lesions, suggesting that they could have been SCLE patients misdiagnosed as RS. Lyon et al.31 described two cases of SCLE initially diagnosed as RS, with EM-like lesions associated with positive Ro/SSA antibodies and RF, but further histopathological analysis finally suggested the diagnosis of SCLE.

In several cases, direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of the EM-like lesions was performed together with the histopathological examination. Interestingly, in all of the cases of EM associated with LED, DIF was negative54,56,59,62 or showed non-specific findings such as perivascular deposition of Ig,6 whilst in 14 out of 22 cases of EM associated with SLE, junctional deposits of Ig and complement could be found in the EM-like lesions. Thus, DIF findings could represent a diagnostic criterion to differentiate between EM-like and SCLE lesions, since a junctional deposition of Ig and C can be found only in the latter, unless EM is associated with SLE.

The presence of chilblains (considered by Zeitouni et al.70 as a minor diagnostic criterion) was reported only in 14.9% of cases. It has been hypothesized that the presence of speckled ANA may be part of the immunologic features contributing to the formation of chilblain lesions.75 Additionally, most patients with chilblains often showed a positive RF. Therefore, it is possible that both the speckled ANA and the RF are actually associated with perniosis.7,74 In fact, chilblains are one of the more common cutaneous manifestations in the spectrum of cutaneous LE, and speckled ANA and RF are strongly associated with chilblain lupus variant and should not be considered as specific markers.75

The speckled pattern of ANA, thought to be one of the most consistent immunologic features of RS and reported in 60.4% of patients with RS, is positive also in a significant proportion of SLE, mixed connective tissue disease, and systemic sclerosis patients, so it is not unique to RS.90

RF positivity, always present in the cases described by Rowell et al., was reported only in 42.9% of the following cases from the literature (Table 2). Its presence in DLE (17%), SLE (40%), systemic sclerosis (40%), SCLE, and Sjögren’s syndrome also disclaims its uniqueness to RS.91

The same stands for anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, which were found in 59% of the patients with RS, but have been detected in 60–90% of SCLE patients, and also in Sjögren’s syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis and systemic sclerosis; furthermore, they are strongly associated with photosensitivity and vasculitis in SLE.92

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In conclusion, based on our own experience44 and on an accurate review of the literature, we observed that, in the majority of cases, different entities were reported under the name of RS. In particular, patients with an association between SCLE annular-polycyclic type and DLE or ACLE (malar rash or, less frequently, maculo-papular rash or bullous rash) were incorrectly diagnosed as having RS.
Thus, according with other authors,8,66,74,84,93 we suggest that LE with EM-like rashes represents a subset of SCLE with targetoid lesions rather than a distinct entity.

A real association between DLE and EM was present only in a minority of cases (about 20 patients) and could be considered a mere coincidence without any immunopathological implication or unusual characteristic to either illness. As for other associations, for example those between CLE and lichen planus or psoriasis, the coexistence of CLE and EM does not justify the framing of a separate syndrome as originally suggested by Rowell et al.1

sec.title: Conflict of interest statement
sec.p: None.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
